title: How to Stop an Itchy Nose

steps.title: Use a cool-mist humidifier.
steps.content: Use a cool-mist humidifier. Run a cool-mist humidifier in your bedroom at night according to the manufacturer’s instructions. This will put increased moisture in the air to lubricate your nasal passages and ease itchiness and irritation. [2] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Clean your cool-mist humidifier regularly to keep mold and bacteria from growing in the water. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Try saline nose drops.
steps.content: Try saline nose drops. Use an over-the-counter saline nasal spray to lubricate your itchy nasal passages. Breathe in slowly through your nose as you spritz the spray in each nostril according to the manufacturer’s directions. [4] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Family Physicians Organization devoted to improving the health of patients, families, and communities Go to source This will help clean irritants out of your nose and ease itching. [5] X Research source Blow your nose if needed after using your saline spray. Administer your saline safely up to 2 times per day. If you feel you need it more often, consult your doctor.

steps.title: Drink adequate fluids every day to hydrate your nasal passages.
steps.content: Drink adequate fluids every day to hydrate your nasal passages. Aim to drink 15.5 cups (3.7 liters) of fluids a day if you’re a man, and 11.5 cups (2.7 liters) of fluids a day if you are a woman. [6] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Sufficient water intake will ensure that your nasal tissues are lubricated, preventing itchiness caused by dehydration. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Apply a water-soluble lubricant to the inside of your nose.
steps.content: Apply a water-soluble lubricant to the inside of your nose. Apply a pea-sized amount of water-soluble personal lubricant, such as KY jelly, to the inside of your nostrils with a clean cotton swab. Use as little as necessary to feel relief, and do not use the lubricant within a few hours of lying down. [8] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Avoid oil-based lubricants, such as petroleum jelly, which can migrate to the lungs and cause infection. You can purchase water-soluble lubricant at your local drug store or online.

steps.title: Steer clear of allergic triggers.
steps.content: Steer clear of allergic triggers. Avoid common allergic irritants, especially if you notice your nasal itchiness worsens after being around them. Animal dander, dust, pollen, cigarette smoke, and mold can all cause your nose to become itchy. [9] X Research source Buying a HEPA-grade air filter, keeping your pet out of your bedroom, and washing your bedding in hot water once a week will reduce your allergen exposure. [10] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Try over-the-counter allergy medicines.
steps.content: Try over-the-counter allergy medicines. Use an over-the-counter allergy medicine, such as Diphenhydramine or Loratadine, to relieve your itchy nose, watery eyes, and other allergy symptoms. Take over-the-counter allergy medications according to the manufacturer’s instructions. [11] X Research source Note that some allergy drugs may cause drowsiness, especially Chlorpheniramine and Diphenhydramine. It can be helpful to take the medication for the first time on a day when you have less to do, so you can see how it affects you. Ask your pharmacist about any potential drug interactions between your current medication regimen and your over-the-counter allergy medication.

steps.title: Make an appointment with an allergist.
steps.content: Make an appointment with an allergist. Contact a local allergist to discuss your symptoms and perform diagnostic allergy testing if your symptoms don’t improve. If you’re in the U.S., you can search for an allergist in your area on the American College of Allergy, Asthma, and Immunology website: http://acaai.org/locate-an-allergist . [12] X Research source Bring any notes about when your itchy nose started, how long it has been going on, and anything that seems to trigger the itchiness. Often the doctor will request that you stop over-the-counter allergy medications before your appointment for the most conclusive allergy testing.

steps.title: Talk to your doctor about nasal corticosteroids.
steps.content: Talk to your doctor about nasal corticosteroids. Ask your doctor if nasal corticosteroids would be helpful to treat your itchy nose. These prescription medications reduce swelling in your nasal passages, calming irritation and itchiness caused by seasonal allergies. [13] X Research source Long-term use of corticosteroids comes with some risks, such as damage to the nasal passages. Talk to your doctor about using the steroids intermittently (i.e., only when you need them), and find the lowest possible dose that controls your itchy nose and other symptoms. [14] X Research source If you use corticosteroids long-term, your doctor will need to do checkups occasionally to make sure they are not causing any harmful effects.

steps.title: Discuss allergy shots for severe symptoms.
steps.content: Discuss allergy shots for severe symptoms. Ask your doctor about allergy shots, also called immunotherapy, if your symptoms don’t improve with prescription medication. Allergy shots are therapeutic injections that expose you to allergens in incremental doses to decrease your sensitivity to them. In time, this reduces your allergic symptoms. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Minimize your smoke exposure.
steps.content: Minimize your smoke exposure. Ask smokers to smoke outside your home, and start smoking cessation therapy if you need to quit . Smoke can cause irritation and swelling of your nasal passages, which may feel itchy. [16] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Your doctor can help you find and start a program to quit smoking.

steps.title: Keep a dust-free home.
steps.content: Keep a dust-free home. Remove knickknacks that collect dust, such as tabletop ornaments or books, and clean your home regularly. Even if you’re not allergic, dust particles can irritate your nasal passages, causing inflammation and itching. If possible, arrange for someone else to clean your home, so dust that’s kicked up in the cleaning process doesn’t further irritate you. [17] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Make an appointment with your doctor for a checkup.
steps.content: Make an appointment with your doctor for a checkup. Visit your doctor to see if a virus, such as the flu, or a bacterial infection, such as a sinus infection, could be causing your nasal itchiness. Though this is less common than nasal dryness or allergies, it is possible if you’ve otherwise been feeling unwell. [18] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Certain chronic health problems, such as chronic fatigue syndrome and underactive thyroid, can cause an itchy nose. Discuss these possibilities with your doctor.

steps.title: Embrace healthy drinking habits.
steps.content: Embrace healthy drinking habits. Aim to drink no more than 2 alcoholic drinks in a given day, if you are a man. Women should aim to drink no more than 1 drink per day. [19] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source Alcohol can cause your nasal membranes to swell, making them itchy and irritated. [20] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Monitor hormonal changes.
steps.content: Monitor hormonal changes. Note if your nasal itchiness coincided with a hormonal shift due to pregnancy, menopause, menstruation, or starting hormonal birth control. If so, it could be to blame for your symptoms. These changes can all cause itchy nasal passages. [21] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Discuss your nasal symptoms with your doctor, who can help you figure out how to address them. It may be an option to change hormonal birth control pills, for example.

steps.title: Look into the impact of any new medications you're taking.
steps.content: Look into the impact of any new medications you're taking. Discuss your symptoms with your doctor if you noticed nasal itchiness after beginning a new medication. Aspirin, ibuprofen, beta-blockers, and some high-blood-pressure medications can cause nasal irritation and itchiness. [22] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Your doctor may be able to suggest a different medication or a new approach to ease your side effects.

steps.title: Avoid prolonged use of nasal decongestants.
steps.content: Avoid prolonged use of nasal decongestants. Don’t use nasal decongestant sprays, such as Afrin, for more than 3 days at a time. While these sprays reduce swelling and can help relieve itchiness, prolonged use often causes rebound congestion with a worsening of symptoms. [23] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source
